conclusion: The early warning radar detects an enemy aircraft flying horizontally at a constant speed at an altitude of 20000m.
An anti-aircraft missile with a mass of m=100kg is launched.
The missile's rocket engine expels gas vertically downward, causing the missile to accelerate uniformly upward from rest with an acceleration of a=10g until it reaches an altitude of 5000m.
At 5000m, the direction of the gas expulsion changes to an angle θ (cosθ=1/11) downward and to the right, causing the missile to follow a curved trajectory.
The rocket thrust remains constant during the missile's flight, and the missile's mass change and air resistance are negligible.
The missile can be treated as a point mass, and g=10m/s².
When a missile undergoes curvilinear motion, the magnitudes of the horizontal and vertical accelerations are ax and ay respectively.

premise: Using the kinematic equation: h = v₀t + (1/2)at², and v₀ = 0
The velocity at h = 5000 m is: v = v₀ + at = 0 + 100 × 10

conclusion: Gravitational force: F_g = mg = 100 kg × 10 m/s² = 1000 N downward

premise: During vertical motion, the net force was: F_net = ma = m(a-g) = m × 9g = 100 × 9 × 10
So the thrust force magnitude is 10,000 N (to produce net upward acceleration of 9g when fighting gravity).
